content:
Sure, here is a Linux lab exercise with more than 30 commands where students can try each command and state its function:

1. pwd
2. cd
3. ls
4. mkdir
5. touch
6. rm
7. mv
8. cp
9. echo
10. cat
11. find
12. man
13. tar
14. gzip
15. gunzip
16. file
17. chmod
18. chown
19. chgrp
20. ps
21. top
22. kill
23. uname
24. df
25. du
26. ifconfig
27. netstat
28. hostname
29. ping
30. traceroute
31. ssh
32. scp
33. wget
34. curl
35. grep
36. sed
37. awk
38. tee
39. cut
40. sort

Lab exercise:

1. Type "pwd" to display the current working directory.
2. Type "cd /home/user/Documents" to change to the Documents directory.
3. Type "ls" to list the contents of the current directory.
4. Type "mkdir new\_directory" to create a new directory called "new\_directory".
5. Type "touch new\_file.txt" to create a new file called "new\_file.txt".
6. Type "rm new\_file.txt" to delete the "new\_file.txt" file.
7. Type "mv file1.txt /home/user/Desktop" to move the "file1.txt" file to the Desktop directory.
8. Type "cp file1.txt file2.txt /home/user/Desktop" to copy the "file1.txt" and "file2.txt" files to the Desktop directory.
9. Type "echo Hello World!" to print "Hello World!" to the standard output.
10. Type "cat file1.txt" to display the contents of the "file1.txt" file.
11. Type "find /home/user/Documents -name file1.txt" to search for the "file1.txt" file in the "Documents" directory.
12. Type "man ls" to display the manual page for the "ls" command.
13. Type "tar -cvzf archive.tar.gz file1.txt file2.txt" to compress the "file1.txt" and "file2.txt" files into an archive called "archive.tar.gz".
14. Type "gzip file1.txt" to compress the "file1.txt" file into a gzip file called "file1.txt.gz".
15. Type "gunzip file1.txt.gz" to decompress the "file1.txt.gz" file.
16. Type "file file1.txt" to display the file type of the "file1.txt" file.
17. Type "chmod 755 file1.txt" to set the permissions of the "file1.txt" file to 755.
18. Type "chown user file1.txt" to change the ownership of the "file1.txt" file to the "user" user.
19. Type "chgrp group file1.txt" to change the group ownership of the "file1.txt" file to the "group" group.
20. Type "ps aux" to display the processes running on the system.
21. Type "top" to display the system information and the running processes.
22. Type "kill PID" to terminate the process with the specified PID.
23. Type "uname -a" to display the system information, including the kernel version.
24. Type "df" to display the disk space usage of the file systems.
25. Type "du -sh directory" to display the disk space usage of the specified directory.
26. Type "ifconfig"
